column2: mazie, 65-74 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have taken years ago.. and it worked

column2: Josh, 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've had trouble sleeping for a few years now. I would go to sleep at 1 AM, cannot fall asleep, get up for another hour or two, finally go back to bed, and then fall asleep around 4-5 AM. But, I would have to get out of bed at anywhere from 9 AM - 1 PM. That said, was only getting anywhere from 3-6 hours of sleep. I also use a FitBit Ultra (it has other uses) which for sleeping purposes, tracks my motion, how much I move, not brain waves, unlike Sleep Managers like Zeo.  That said, after 1 night of Restoril I went to bed at 1:30 AM, fell asleep, for once! I didn't keep waking up like I normally do between 6:30-8:30 and slept until 10 AM, woke up, then fell back asleep for another hour. When it was all said and done, my FitBit said I was in bed for 9 hr 36 min and slept 8 hrs 17 min. This is a HUGE improvement, even after 1 pill. My doctor gave me 2 refills. I will update later. I do obviously have a lot of sleep to catch up on.  Like others have reported, though, after my first usage, I felt groggy and hung-over.  That said, this pill to me is like 1 1/2 bottles of red wine minus the calories.  I can't wait to sleep more!

column2: JEM, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to less than 2 years (Patient)
column9: The only way I become slightly sleeping is if I take 30 mg plus - and only on an empty stomach. If I eat dinner, then there is no effect at all. So I eat an early large lunch and skip dinner if I want to sleep. For some reason, I have a high tolerance to meds in general, whether it be otc pain relievers or cold tabs. On the other hand, my husband can take a vitamin and swears he has more energy days later. Why is my resistance so high? I do not have a history of taking many meds, so this is baffling.

column2: 75 or over Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: My husband who is an MD and I think this drug is wonderful.   We always take it on long, overseas plane trips, sleep well and wake up refreshed and alert.  When not traveling we only use it occasionally.   Always works for us.

column2: Karen, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: With Fibro and bilateral hip replacements, pain and RLS has prevented me from a restful nights sleep for years.  I was constantly tossing and turning trying to find a position that didn't hurt.I took Ambien for a while, but recently I began waking up after an hour or so and usually ended up in the kitchen eating.  And I could always feel the pain (everywhere) even though I was sleeping.  I finally asked my doc for Restoril (30mg)last week and I have had some of the best night's sleep than I've had in years!!  Restful sleep helps in pain management for Fibro, so hopefully this will improve too.

column2: louise86, 19-24 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month
column9: Hi, I have recently been diagnosed with panic disorder and GAD. My anxiety spiraled out of control really rapidly and I was having trouble stopping my racing thoughts at night. I found xanax left me really smacked out and then tried seroquel and had a raging appetite as well as akathisia and tremors... I've been taking temazepam (restoril) for about 3 weeks now and have been sleeping incredibly well but I'm starting to worry about some of the worse side effects eg. blurred vision. Has anyone else experienced this sort of side effect with restoril? otherwise, it's great

column9: Like many of the comments I find that this medication doesn't work right away.  I found that taking it around 9 PM I fall asleep around 1030 or 11.  Really works well for my restless legs too.

column2: sleeplessinAZ, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I suffer from major migraines so am unable to sleep at night.  I was on Lunesta and then Ambien CR which after a few months both quit working.  I've been using this medication (30 mg)for three nights and I've had to take my tranquilizer and muscle relaxer in order to fall asleep.  This takes over 2 hours to work.  I will be asking my dr to prescribe something more effective for me.

column2: 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
Mike, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I was falling asleep easily enough, but would always wake at around 1:30 am and then every 20-30 minutes afterward, making a good night's rest impossible. I take 30mg and it has greatly aided me in sleeping through the night - because it's for temporary relief, I did not take it last night to see if I could do without it and was back to the constant waking.  When taking Restoril I do feel slightly groggy in the morning when I wake, but it wears off quickly one you're up and moving.  I'll gladly accept that over the effects of chronic sleep deprivation.  I have had no experiences with sleepwalking or any other negative effects while taking this.  It does state that the med is for temporary use, so I still need to work on the root cause of the waking, but I am highly satisfied with the short-term benefit.  This medicine may not be the one for you if you have a hard time falling asleep - I can stay awake for quite a while after taking it if I'm working on something that holds my attention.  This is more for maintaining sleep duration than for falling asleep, whereas Ambien will help with falling asleep (per my Dr.).If you are experiencing a lot of waking through the night, I would definitely recommend asking your doctor about it.

column2: Phil, 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)

column9: I have chronic insomnia as well as anxiety. I have been on several different medications for sleep and anxiety in the past, and none have worked for my sleep. I researched Restoril and asked my neurologist if it was possible if I could try it. I have been on it for two weeks. It has worked wonders, except now I'm not falling asleep when I take the pill. I'm on 15mg. When I take the pill, I always fall asleep. Now I'm awake for three to four hours afterwards. Is this normal, or has anyone experienced this after taking the drug for this long?

column2: annette, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I am having breakthrough pain throughout the night (I'm pre-hip replacement) and not sleeping.  My doctor prescribed this drug because Ambien was not really working for me and made me "sleep eat".  I took it for the first time tonight and have been up all night feeling shaky and kind of jacked up.  This is the 4th or 5th night of no or constantly interrupted sleep and its taking its toll.  I'm not sure why I'm having the complete opposite effect with a sleep aid but this drug is just not for me and is going in the toilet!

column2: 65-74 Male  on Treatment for 2 to less than 5 years (Patient)
column9: I take restoril about 3 times a week and am very sleepy within 45 min...I sleep peacefully all night..at least for 8 hours and wake up refreshed. Great response.

column2: mitchfdr@gmail.com, 45-54 Male  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
lefty, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: It took 4 hours for me to even start to feel tired, but I never did get to sleep. would not recommend this to ant insomniac.

column2: jodymacarthur, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I HATE THIS MED! I just recently went to full dose (15mg) at bedtime after getting off of Klonopin for sleep disorder/insommnia which I was on for a few years. Today, I feel absolutely awful after experiencing the WORST night in my recent memory. I do have Fibromyalgia and Sjogren's Syndrome so I'm on a lot of meds already, but I feel worse from side effects than I do from without sleeping at all - headache, tremors, eye pressure/pain, shakiness, and feeling really spaced out. It takes forever to get to sleep and when I do, I find myself waking up every few hours in between really weird and vivid dreams. Paying an $85/mo copay for GENERIC Restoril doesn't do too much to thrill me either. Calling Dr. ASAP to change to something else. Not worth the money or the possibility for addiction/codependence!

column2: 25-34 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Patient)
column9: I've been having what I believe to be anxiety related insomnia.  After about 5-6 days on about 4-5 hours of sleep I saw a doctor who prescribed me temazepam (restoril).  After about 1 1/2 hours it got me to sleep but I always wake up after about 5 hours.  It's difficult to get back to sleep when I wake up.  I was given 15mg doses and have taken 30 with no improvement with the higher dose.  That being said I've tried ambien cr and it works wonderfully for me.  I do like the restoril as I haven't woken up feeling groggy or hungover, just a little tired.  It helps to find out how long it takes you to fall asleep on it then take one pill.  Once you're about to fall asleep take another one.  That gave me about 6 1/2 hours.

column2: Bellster, 55-64 Male  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I have been taking this RX for about 3 weeks and suddenly, I started waking up almost totally disoriented and confused; but the worst problem was (quit today) it causing my heart to feel like it was going to explode.  It is very much like the symptoms I had with Seroquel and Ambien.  I agree with the person who wrote a review about finding out more about the RX you take. DO NOT just trust the doctor to act in your best interest.  I have been treated for depression and sleep disorder since about 1989.  It has been my experience that most psychiatrists do not take the time to understand your particular symptoms and how you are responding to the RX.  They seem to run you through like a heard of cattle and are far to irresponsible (in my opinion) in prescribing the class and amount of RX.

column2: Sleepseeker, 55-64 Female  (Patient)

I only have trouble sleeping occasionally.  Thanks!

column2: hersheysmore, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: I have become a very light sleeper over the past several years thanks to a few underlying medical conditions that cause me to wake up at night to use the bathroom or because of low back pain.  I was prescribed Lunesta, which helped me fall asleep, but didnt keep me asleep at night and left me with an awful aftertaste in my mouth in the mornings. Then I was given the RX for the Restoril.  I had a few people who were on it tell me NOT to take it because it made them feel groggy all day after taking it the night before.  Well, I finally broke down weeks later and tried it.  I love it.  I take it about 45  mins before I am ready for bed and it helps me fall to sleep easy and for the most part keeps me asleep at night. The biggest downfall is the expense.  Another problem, is that I cannot fall asleep with out the aid of sleeping medication.  I lie in bed for hours if I dont take something and I do not think it is because of the Restoril.  I was like that with the Lunesta and the OTC sleep aids too.  I avoid caffeine late in the day and I still dont fall asleep.  This has gone on for years and my husband now sleeps in a separate bedroom because the slightest noise (snoring) will keep me up all night.I say give the medicine a try.  There are so many on the market now, one is bound to work.  I just dont like being dependent on them to sleep and they are not the easiest thing to wean off of when you need your rest.

column9: Started on this medication after Trazadone worked well only for the first night I took it.  Restoril 30mgs works for me for 4-5 hours which is OK because that is better than tossing and turning afer getting only one hour of sleep.  I now only take it every other night because when I first started it and took it for four nights in a row on the fourth night I had an awful nightmare which I do not want to experience ever again.  Taking it every other night I haven't experience any nightmares.  I toss and turn all night low on the night I don't take it.

column2: bob-o-link14, 35-44 Male  on Treatment for less than 1 month (Caregiver)
column9: Beware! My elderly father is taking this while on hospice, and it made him a zombie with less then half the ambulatory mobility than what he had when he doesn't take it. It did not help his sleeping at all.

column2: JAFUD, 35-44 Female  on Treatment for 10 years or more (Patient)
column9: I was prescribed this medication along with Valium when I was diagnosed as Bipolar.  I take 30 mg at bedtime and 10 mg of Valium at bedtime.  The medicine worked very well for a little while.  However, I have been taking this medication now going on 12 YEARS!  This medication is a HYPNOTIC sleep-aid that should only be taken for short-term treatment of insomnia.  When I told my Psychiatrist that I was having trouble sleeping and that the medicines weren't effective, she prescribed SEROQUEL 500 mg at bedtime to boot!  Don't allow anyone to cause you to abuse, misuse, or become dependent/addicted to ANY medication.  If it is not having an effect any longer...there might be a real good reason why.  Educate yourself on the medications you and/or a loved one is prescribed.  Just because a doctor prescribes the medication, doesn't mean you don't have the right to ask questions about it's usage.

column2: support95, 25-34 Female  on Treatment for 6 months to less than 1 year (Patient)
column9: I suffer from many different health problems, of which, Fibromyalgia & Sleep Apnea are 2. I have trouble most nights w/ staying asleep,but I also do have times where I have trouble falling asleep. This is 1 of the many different meds I've tried for my sleep problems, but again I've run into a typical problem on this med,just like the others I've taken. The day after I take the med to sleep I'm extremly tired (fatigue)and drowsy, sometimes not waking up until 1 or 2pm., but if I don't take the med, like last night, I'm up the entire night never going to sleep and then the next day I'm again faced w/ the same problemssupport of the extreme fatigue and drowsiness.I really don't know what to do anymore. I am taking a few other meds that can cause fatigue and drowsiness also, so I'm sure that's alot of the problem, so just be aware, if your taking other meds, of their side effects and the possibilty of getting into this exhausting routine I'm in and don't know the answer to.

column2: survivor, 45-54 Female  on Treatment for 1 to 6 months (Patient)
column9: This medicine worked very well to fall asleep and worked moderately well to stay asleep.  I did experience intense dreaming.  I had side effects during and after using this medication.  I experienced tremors, confusion, memory loss, poor coordination, weakness and difficulty concentrating.  Much of these symptoms lessened  by cutting the dose in half.  I discontinued the medication but developed rebound insomnia and a severe headache for eleven days  Most of the side effects I mentioned took about 6 weeks to fully subside after discontinuation.   I still have insomnia.
